clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo's subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This city is built on seven hills and houses an ancient oval amphitheater.
You can throw coins into a famous fountain to ensure your return to this city.
fun_fact: The Trevi Fountain collects about €3,000 every day, which is donated to charity.
This city has more than 2,000 fountains, more than any other city in the world.
trivia: The Colosseum could hold up to 80,000 spectators in its heyday.
Romans were among the first to develop apartment living with their 'insulae' buildings.

clues: This harbor city features a famous opera house with sail-shaped shells.
Home to the world's largest steel arch bridge, affectionately called 'The Coathanger'.
fun_fact: The Sydney Opera House has over one million roof tiles covering approximately 1.62 hectares.
Sydney's Bondi Beach lifeguards perform over 5,000 rescues each year.
trivia: The Sydney Harbour Bridge took eight years to build and was completed in 1932.
The city's name comes from British Home Secretary Thomas Townshend, Lord Sydney.

clues: This city stands near one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
The world's oldest wonder sits at the edge of this metropolitan area.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza was the tallest man-made structure in the world for nearly 4,000 years.
This city's name in Arabic means 'The Victorious' or 'The Conqueror'.
trivia: Cairo is home to Al-Azhar University, one of the oldest universities in the world, founded in 970 CE.
The city has a traffic problem so severe that locals joke that the loudest sound in Cairo is car horns.

clues: This coastal city is watched over by a massive statue with arms stretched wide.
Home to the world's largest Carnival celebration and famous for its stunning beaches.
fun_fact: The Christ the Redeemer statue was struck by lightning in 2014, causing damage to one of its fingers.
The name of this city translates to 'January River', though there is actually no river there.
trivia: Rio's Carnival attracts about 2 million people per day to its street parades.
The famous Copacabana Beach stretches for 4.5 kilometers and is made of imported sand.

clues: This city has canals instead of streets and over 400 bridges connecting its 118 islands.
Famous for its carnival masks and gondola boats steered by singing navigators.
fun_fact: Venice is sinking at a rate of 1-2 millimeters per year.
There are no cars or roads in the historic center of this city, only boats and pedestrian paths.
trivia: The city's famous Rialto Bridge is over 400 years old and was the only way to cross the Grand Canal on foot until the 1850s.
Marco Polo, the famous explorer, was born in Venice around 1254.

clues: This Mediterranean city features an unfinished cathedral that's been under construction since 1882.
Known for its unique modernist architecture and buildings with colorful mosaics.
fun_fact: The Sagrada Familia is expected to be completed in 2026, the centenary of Gaudí's death, although construction may continue beyond that date.
This city has a beach that didn't exist until it was artificially created for the 1992 Olympics.
trivia: Barcelona has 9 UNESCO World Heritage Sites, most of which were designed by Antoni Gaudí.
The city's famous La Rambla street was once a sewage-filled stream.

clues: This city boasts the tallest building in the world and man-made islands shaped like palm trees.
A desert metropolis known for its ultra-modern architecture and luxury shopping.
fun_fact: The Burj Khalifa is so tall that you can watch the sunset from the base, then take an elevator to the top and watch it set again.
This city has the world's largest choreographed fountain system, which shoots water up to 500 feet in the air.
trivia: In 1991, this city had only one skyscraper; now it has over 400.
Dubai has the world's only 7-star hotel, though the rating is unofficial.

clues: This transcontinental city straddles two continents divided by a narrow strait.
Once the capital of three major empires, it features a famous domed structure that was once the world's largest cathedral.
fun_fact: The Grand Bazaar is one of the world's oldest and largest covered markets, with over 4,000 shops.
This city is home to over 3,000 mosques, with their calls to prayer creating a unique daily soundscape.
trivia: Istanbul was previously known as Byzantium and later Constantinople.
Tulips, now associated with the Netherlands, were actually first cultivated by the Ottomans and exported to Holland from Istanbul.

clues: This former imperial capital is known for its classical Buddhist temples and gardens.
Famous for its traditional wooden houses and geisha district with preserved tea houses.
fun_fact: This city was spared from atomic bombing during WWII because of its cultural significance.
There are over 1,600 Buddhist temples and 400 Shinto shrines in this city.
trivia: Kyoto was Japan's capital city for more than 1,000 years until 1868.
The city's grid layout was modeled after the ancient Chinese capital of Chang'an (present-day Xi'an).

clues: This 'Red City' features a maze-like medina and a famous square filled with snake charmers and storytellers.
Known for its vibrant souks, gardens, and historic palaces with ornate tile work.
fun_fact: The walls of this city are made of red clay, giving it its nickname 'The Red City'.
Jemaa el-Fnaa square transforms completely from day to night, changing from a market to an open-air restaurant.
trivia: Marrakech was founded in 1062 by Abu Bakr ibn Umar, a chieftain of the Almoravid dynasty.
The city's name comes from the Berber words 'mur' and 'akush', meaning 'Land of God'.

clues: This city is known as the 'City of a Hundred Spires' and features a famous astronomical clock.
Home to the largest ancient castle complex in the world, overlooking a river that divides the city.
fun_fact: Prague Castle covers an area of almost 70,000 square meters, making it the largest coherent castle complex in the world.
The city's famous Charles Bridge is adorned with 30 statues, most of which are replicas as the originals are kept in a museum.
trivia: The Prague Astronomical Clock was installed in 1410, making it the third-oldest in the world and the oldest still operating.
Franz Kafka, the famous writer, was born and lived in Prague for most of his life.

clues: This coastal city sits beneath a famous flat-topped mountain.
Home to a notorious island prison where a future president was once held captive.
fun_fact: Table Mountain has over 2,200 species of plants, more than the entire United Kingdom.
This city is located near the point where the Atlantic and Indian Oceans meet, creating unique weather patterns.
trivia: Cape Town is the oldest city in South Africa, established in 1652 as a supply station for Dutch ships.
Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 18 years, is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

clues: This canal-ringed city has more bridges than Venice and is known for its narrow houses with gabled facades.
Famous for its bicycle culture and museums housing works by Van Gogh and Rembrandt.
fun_fact: There are more bicycles than people in this city, with estimates suggesting 1.1 bicycles per person.
Many houses in the city are deliberately built leaning forward to facilitate moving furniture up through the windows.
trivia: Amsterdam has over 100 kilometers of canals, lined by about 1,500 bridges.
The Anne Frank House, where the famous diarist hid during WWII, is one of the city's most visited museums.

clues: This South American capital is known as the 'Paris of South America' for its European architecture.
Famous for tango dancing and colorful neighborhoods where soccer is a religion.
fun_fact: This city has the widest avenue in the world, Avenida 9 de Julio, which spans 140 meters with 14 lanes.
El Ateneo Grand Splendid, a converted theater, is considered one of the most beautiful bookstores in the world.
trivia: Buenos Aires has the highest concentration of theaters in the world, with over 300 theaters.
The city's subway system, opened in 1913, is the oldest in South America and the Southern Hemisphere.

clues: This hilly city is known for its iconic red bridge often shrouded in fog.
Famous for its cable cars, Victorian houses, and former prison island.
fun_fact: The Golden Gate Bridge's distinctive color is officially called 'International Orange' and was originally intended to be a temporary primer.
This city's Lombard Street is known as the 'crookedest street in the world' with eight sharp hairpin turns.
trivia: San Francisco is built on more than 50 hills, with Twin Peaks offering some of the best views of the city.
The city experienced a devastating earthquake in 1906 that destroyed over 80% of the city.

clues: This Southeast Asian capital is known for its ornate shrines and vibrant street life.
Home to a famous reclining Buddha and floating markets on its extensive canals.
fun_fact: This city has the longest official name of any place in the world at 168 letters, though it's commonly abbreviated.
The city is sinking 2-3 centimeters every year due to excessive groundwater pumping and the weight of massive buildings.
trivia: Bangkok's full ceremonial name begins with 'Krungthepmahanakhon' and takes about 30 seconds to pronounce correctly.
The city has over 400 Buddhist temples (wats), each with its unique architectural style.
